items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling slowly on the River Pang. However, flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible, especially in areas close to the river around Tidmarsh due to high groundwater levels. The beginning of the week is expected to be mainly dry, with some bands of rain and isolated showers possible towards the end of the week. We expect river levels to continue to gradually fall, but levels will be sensitive to rainfall. 
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 12:45pm tomorrow, Saturday 29th March. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.60mAODN at 11:45am, on Saturday 29th March, which is 0.48m above tide tables, wind force 2, Southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The tide on Sunday 30th March at 1:30pm (British Summer Time) is also currently forecast to be at Flood Alert level. We will send a new message before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm on Saturday 29th March.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 12:45pm tomorrow, Saturday 29th March. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.60mAODN at 11:45am, on Saturday 29th March, which is 0.48m above tide tables, wind force 2, Southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The tide on Sunday 30th March at 1:30pm (British Summer Time) is also currently forecast to be at Flood Alert level. We will send a new message before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm on Saturday 29th March.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.80 mAOD at 14:30 on 29/03/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 55 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 29/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible for a few hours either side of high water at 7:15 AM on 29/03/2025.
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We have closed flood gates at Pill.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 7:15 AM on 29/03/2025 with a level of 7.45 mAODN with westerly force 3 winds. This Flood Alert is likely to be in force until Tuesday 1st April.
This message will be updated in the afternoon of 29/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides are expected from Saturday 29th March through to Wednesday 2nd April which may cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast. This flood alert covers the high tide between 10:00 AM on 29/03/2025 and 12:00 noon on 29/03/2025, with the highest tide level expected around 11:00AM. A flood alert is also expected for the evening tide 29/03/25 at 23:00.

Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
Further flooding is possible overnight due to higher than normal tides combined with north-northwesterly hurricane force 12 winds and large offshore waves. 

Our incident rooms are open and we are closing flood gates, where needed.  Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 29/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides from 29 March 2025 may lead to flooding. This alert is for the high tide at 11:00AM on 29 March 2025 with further detail as follows;

Peak Water Level: 5.20mAOD
Time of Peak Water Level: 11:00-11:15 GMT
Time of High Astronomical Tide (tide table): 11:02 GMT
High Astronomical Tide Level (tide table): 4.97mAOD
Wind Direction: South West

Subsequent high tides up to and including the mid day high tide on 01/04/2025 are expected to reach the Flood Alert level.  This message will be updated by 08:00AM on 29/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray tonight and tomorrow, Saturday 29/03/2025 between 4.45am and 7.15am. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Property flooding is not expected. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point, including Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. Further flooding is possible over the weekend due to high spring tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9:00am Saturday 29/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am and 12:45pm tomorrow, Saturday 29th March. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may experience some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.82mAODN at 11:45am, on Saturday 29th March, which is 0.26m above tide tables, wind force 2, Southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables).  The tide on Sunday 30th March at 1.30pm (British Summer Time) is also currently forecast to be at Flood Alert level. We will send a new message before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm on Saturday 29th March.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high spring tides are expected over the next 3 days. Commencing with the high tide on Saturday morning, flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow.
Predicted peaks. Newport 6.6 to 6.8m at 18:30 on 28/03/2025 and 7.0 to 7.2m at 07:00 on 29/03/2025.
Avonmouth Portbury 6.9 to 7.1m at 18:45 on 28/03/2025 and 7.4 to 7.6m at 07:15 on 29/03/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 29/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray tonight and tomorrow, Saturday 29/03/2025 between 4.30am and 8am. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Property flooding is not expected. Areas most at risk include the Humber Estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. Further flooding is possible over the weekend due to high spring tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message at 9:00am Saturday 29/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am and 1:15pm tomorrow, Saturday 29th March. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.40mAODN at 12:15pm, on Saturday 29th March, which is 0.22m above tide tables, wind force 4, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The tide on Sunday 30th March at 2pm (British Summer Time) is also currently forecast to be at Flood Alert level. We will send a new message before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm on Saturday 29th March.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high, but are falling slowly, on the Winterbourne Stream and the River Lambourn due to high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Bagnor area. The beginning of the week is expected to be mainly dry, with some bands of rain and isolated showers possible towards the end of the week. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. Levels will be sensitive to further rainfall.
Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 31/03/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are slowly falling, but remain over the flood alert thresholds. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. There is no significant rainfall forecast this week. We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 02/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels, in the Candovers and Old Alresford, are high but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 8cm. At Old Alresford, the level has fallen by 10cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall and flooding impacts will decrease. Flood impacts are expected to continue well into April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high, but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level has fallen by 19cm. We expect much of the village to experiencing cellar flooding and impacts to the sewerage system. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall and flooding impacts will decrease. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels, in the villages surrounding Andover, are high but slowly falling. At Clanville, the level has fallen by 21cm in the last week. Cellar flooding impacts may be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden and Penton Grafton. Groundwater is likely to be affecting Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton as well as the main road into Penton Grafton. Impacts to the sewerage system in Penton Mewsey and Appleshaw are ongoing. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. If the weather forecast is favourable next week, this Flood Alert will be removed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high, but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Oakley, has fallen by 13cm. In Deane, we expect cellar flooding impacts to be ongoing. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From today (24/03/2025) to Friday (28/03/2025), the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. Flooding impacts are expected to continue into April. We continue to monitor the level and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 31/03/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram. This is due to persistent rainfall in December and January which has led to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message:
The flood warning has been removed. Groundwater levels have receded. Some minor roads may still have flood water across them, however the risk to motorists and property is now reduced. The forecast is for a more settled spell of weather. Continue to take care on roads as road surfaces may have been damaged. Do not attempt to drive through floodwater, as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.

We do not expect further flooding and the flood warning has been removed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and re-issue this warning if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly, at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.
